txt.en: This townperson does not seem terribly delighted with your trick, but it seemed like the right response nonetheless
This townperson does not seem terribly delighted with your trick, but it seemed like the right response nonetheless
This townperson does not seem terribly delighted with your trick, but it seemed like the right response nonetheless

Troves and Trickery is a festival tradition among many cultures, where participants try to please a number of celebrants with their tricks in order to receive a prize.\n\n<rgb=#FF0000> NOTE: This quest will be removed from your quest log when the event it is associated with ends. </rgb>
This townperson is delighted with your trick and with everything else you do

'Harvestmath is such a wonderful time of year. One of my favourite festival traditions is the game of Troves and Trickery.

'To play, you go about finding people to trick throughout Bree-town. They will tell you something, and you must do your best to act out something related to it.

'Are you interested in playing?'

There are many folks in Bree-town who might be interested in participating in your game of Troves and Trickery.\n\nBryony Elmwood has challenged you to a game of Troves and Trickery. You should speak to several townspeople and <rgb=#FF0000>perform tricks</rgb> for their amusement.

'That sounds like an interesting experience you had, [placeholder]. I'm not sure that it's quite what I had in mind to keep with the spirit of Harvestmath, but it sounds like you did some good in Bree-town nonetheless.'
Bryony Elmwood is at the Festival Grounds in Bree.\n\nYou should return to Bryony Elmwood with word of your successes at Troves and Trickery.
'People who are interested in playing will find a way to catch your eye, [placeholder]. All you need to do is go looking for them in Bree-town.'

'Don't I have news for you, traveller! My neighbour, Provincia, was quarreling with her husband so loudly that it quite caught my attention! And you'll never guess what about. Can you guess? I shall tell you what: apparently he would not let her buy silks for a new dress. Whyever would she need a new dress? I cannot imagine why; she has ten already, and they are in decent shape as they are. Do you want to know what I think? I'll warrant she just wants to compete with Bessie Hawthorne's dresses, for I hear Bessie has eleven. I, for one, am quite content with my eight dresses. What do you say to that?'

'I spent all my week's pay in the Auction Hall, I did. You should lend me some money. A fine traveller like yourself must have some money, and I shall turn it into a handsome profit for you. What do you say to that: yes or no?'
Play Troves and Trickery in Bree ([placeholder]/[placeholder])

'My poor head, how it throbs! Pray, do not disturb me, unless you brought me more ale. I know I ought to be ashamed of myself for drinking so much, but what's a man to do? Bill Ferny kept goading me on. Look where it got me....\n\n'My mother will give me an earful when I wander home stinking of beer. Alas, alas!'
Talk to Bryony Elmwood at the Bree Festival Grounds
Talk to Bryony Elmwood at the Bree Festival Grounds

'I dance all day! If I ever stop, my legs will turn to trees, so I dance, dance, dance all day, every day! What can a man do with two trees for legs? They tell me I'm mad, but they will not think so when their legs turn to trees.'
